'''Critical international relations theory''' is a diverse set of schools of thought in [[International Relations]] (IR) that have criticized the theoretical, meta-theoretical and/or political [[status quo]], both in IR theory and in international politics more broadly — from [[positivist]] as well as [[postpositivist]] positions. Positivist critiques include [[Marxism|Marxist and Neo-Marxist]] approaches and certain ("conventional") strands of [[Constructivism in international relations|social constructivism]]. Postpositivist critiques include [[poststructuralism|poststructuralist]], [[postcolonialism|postcolonial]], "critical" [[Constructivism_(international_relations)|constructivist]], [[Critical_theory|Critical Theory]] (in the strict sense used by the [[Frankfurt_school|Frankfurt School]]), [[Neo-Gramscianism|neo-Gramscian]], most [[feminism|feminist]] and some [[English_school_of_international_relations_theory|English School]] approaches, which differ from both realism and liberalism in their [[epistemology|epistemological]] and [[ontology|ontological]] premises.
Such theories are now widely recognized and taught and researched in many universities, but are as yet less common in the United States. They are taught at both undergraduate and postgraduate levels in many major universities outside the US, where a major concern is that "a myopic discipline of IR might contribute to the continued development of a civil society in the U.S. that thinks, reflects and analyzes complex international events through a very narrow set of theoretical lenses"<ref name=journal>{{cite journal |author=Smith, Steve |title=The United States and the Discipline of International Relations: Hegemonic Country, Hegemonic Discipline? |journal=International Studies Review |year=2002 |volume=4 |issue=2 |pages=67–86 |doi=10.1111/1521-9488.00255}}</ref>
